009package imagingbook.common.filter.examples;
010
011import imagingbook.common.filter.generic.GenericFilter;
012import imagingbook.common.filter.generic.GenericFilterVector;
013import imagingbook.common.image.PixelPack;
014import imagingbook.common.util.progress.ConsoleProgressMonitor;
015import imagingbook.common.util.progress.ProgressMonitor;
016import imagingbook.common.util.progress.ProgressMonitorExample;
017
018/**
019 *<p>
020 * This class defines a custom filter implementing {@link GenericFilterVector} 
021 * that reports its progress, which is queried by a {@link ProgressMonitor}
022 * in the {@link #main(String[])} method.
023 * </p>
024 * <p>
025 * In this example the work required for processing each SINGLE pixel is
026 * assumed to be substantial and progress reporting thus goes all the way
027 * down to the single pixel level.
028 * Method {@link #getProgress()} in this case reports how much of the work for
029 * the current pixel is already completed. 
030 * Note that this is for demonstration only and such fine granularity is usually
031 * not needed.
032 * Typically method {@link #getProgress()} needs not to be overridden or
033 * may be defined to return always 1.
034 * </p>
035 * <p>
036 * The OVERALL filter progress (which depends on the image size and the 
037 * number of required filter passes) is calculated automatically by the
038 * associated super classes.
039 * </p>
040 * @author WB
041 *
042 * @see ProgressMonitor
043 * @see ProgressMonitorExample
044 * @see ConsoleProgressMonitor
045 */
046public class FilterProgressExample extends GenericFilterVector {
047
048        // variables for progress reporting
049        private int maxCnt = 5000;
050        private int cnt;
051        
052        @Override
053        protected void initFilter(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) { 
054        }
055        
056        @Override
057        protected void initPass(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {
058        }
059        
060        @Override
061        protected int passesRequired() {
062                return 3;       // needs 3 passes
063        }
064        
065        @Override
066        protected float[] doPixel(PixelPack source, int u, int v) {
067                float[] dummy = new float[3];
068                float sum = 0;
069                cnt = 0;
070                for (int i = 0; i < maxCnt; i++) {
071                        this.cnt = i;
072                        sum += (float) Math.sqrt(i); // some dummy work
073                }
074                cnt = 0;
075                dummy[0] = sum;
076                return dummy;
077        }
078        
079        // -------------------------------------------------------------
080        
081        /**
082         * {@inheritDoc}
083         * <p>
084         * Note: This method returns the filter's progress (degree of completion) for 
085         * the current pixel (see {@link #doPixel(PixelPack, int, int)}).
086         * Typically this fine granularity is not relevant and
087         * the method should either return 1 or not be overridden at all (removed).
088         * </p>
089         */
090        @Override
091        protected double reportProgress() {
092                return (double) this.cnt / this.maxCnt;
093        }
094        
095        // -------------------------------------------------------------
096        
097        /**
098         * Main method for demonstration only.
099         * @param args ignored
100         */
101        public static void main(String[] args) {
102                PixelPack pp = new PixelPack(400, 300, 3, null);                // dummy data for the filter to process
103                GenericFilter filter = new FilterProgressExample();
104                try (ProgressMonitor monitor = new ConsoleProgressMonitor(filter)) { // starts monitoring immediately
105                        monitor.setWaitTime(500);       
106                        filter.applyTo(pp);
107                }       // closed automatically
108        }
109
110}
